claim: A birdwatcher would pursue their hobby at a Philadelphia Eagles game.

supporting.text: Philadelphia Eagles games are loud and crowded environments, which are not conducive to birdwatching.

attacks.text: Philadelphia Eagles games are loud and crowded environments, which are not conducive to birdwatching.
Some bird species, like pigeons or seagulls, are commonly found in urban and crowded areas, including stadiums.
The noise and activity at an Eagles game would still scare away most birds, making sightings rare even for urban-adapted species.
Birdwatchers can adapt their methods, using binoculars or listening for calls even in noisy environments.
The extreme noise levels at football games would drown out bird calls, rendering auditory identification nearly impossible.

supporting.text: The primary activity at an Eagles game is watching football, not observing wildlife.

attacks.text: The primary activity at an Eagles game is watching football, not observing wildlife.
Birdwatchers can observe urban birds like pigeons and sparrows even at football games.
The noise and crowds at an Eagles game would scare away most birds, making observation difficult.
Some birdwatchers specialize in urban bird behavior and may find games an interesting case study.

supporting.text: Birdwatching typically requires quiet and natural settings, which are absent in a stadium.

attacks.text: Birdwatching typically requires quiet and natural settings, which are absent in a stadium.
Some birdwatchers enjoy observing urban birds, such as pigeons or seagulls, which may be present in stadiums.
Urban birds like pigeons and seagulls are often considered pests and not the primary focus of serious birdwatching.
Birdwatching can be adapted to any setting, and enthusiasts might find interest in observing bird behavior in atypical environments.
The noise and chaos of a stadium would make it nearly impossible to observe or identify birds effectively.

supporting.text: The presence of large crowds and artificial lighting at Eagles games would deter most birds from the area.

attacks.text: The presence of large crowds and artificial lighting at Eagles games would deter most birds from the area.
Some bird species, such as pigeons and gulls, are highly adaptable and commonly found in urban areas with large crowds.
Even adaptable birds may avoid the noise and activity of a football game, reducing birdwatching opportunities.
Birdwatchers can observe birds in flight or perching on structures outside the stadium, even if birds avoid the immediate game area.
The focus on the game and limited visibility from stadium seats would make it impractical to birdwatch effectively.
